awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Physiological responses of neural stem cells to low-level silver nanoparticles.
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal: 1553667 -

PI: Spitzer, Nadia Ph.D.

Consumers today are in contact with hundreds of products that boast antimicrobial properties because they contain manufactured silver nanoparticles. These products include wound dressings, food containers, toys, toothbrushes, clothing, cosmetics, and household appliances. The silver nanoparticles may be shed from these products resulting in exposure.  The antibacterial properties of silver have been recognized since before modern medicine; however, the specific shape and size of silver nanoparticles make them act differently than larger forms of silver. Specifically, they may cross barriers that other forms of silver cannot, following repeated exposures. This project examines the responses of brain cells to low-levels of silver nanoparticles such as those that might result from daily exposure. The PI use a special type of brain cell, adult neural cells. The results of this research will improve our understanding of the impact of widespread incorporation of silver nanoparticles in consumer products. It will also contribute to regulatory policies.

The proposed work will investigate the cellular and molecular effects of chronic low-level exposures to silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) on neural physiology and development. It utilizes adult neural cells as a model to test the effects of low levels of AgNPs on neural cell physiology in identified cells in vitro and in vivo. In vitro studies will identify the intracellular signaling pathways targeted by AgNP exposure to mediate deficits in cytoskeletal structure and function. This will be assessed by combining pharmacology with immunocytochemistry, immunoblot, and time-lapse microscopy of differentiating adult neural cells in culture. The passive and active membrane properties of living cells exposed to low-level AgNPs will be measured by patch clamp electrophysiology to quantify effects on cell physiology during differentiation. Building on in vitro findings, neurogenesis in the brain after chronic, sub-lethal oral AgNP exposure will be investigated using rats. This work represents a critical step towards understanding the cellular targets of sub-lethal AgNPs on neural cells with respect to the physiological mechanisms operating in individual cells. The proposed work includes a significant public education effort that involves undergraduate students in bringing science to elementary schools throughout rural West Virginia. Children will learn scientific concepts in fun interactive ways and meet accessible role models for choosing careers in science or technology.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
In light of the widespread and increasing incorporation of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) in diverse products, these unique particles have been classified as an environmental contaminant of emerging concern. Indeed, the EPA has recently issued a call to investigate the biological effect of these particles, shed from common consumer items like toothbrushes, especially on children. Our work promotes understanding of the physiological impacts of AgNPs on cellular function in the brain. This will aid in the development of guidelines regarding the use of AgNPs in consumer products and their release into the environment.

The widespread use of nanoparticulate metals is relatively novel. Due to the unique structure of these particles, they have unusual and unpredictable functions, very different from ionic or atomic forms of the same metal, in biological systems. Understanding the interaction of these particles with biological mechanisms at levels currently considered safe for the metals of which they are made will be key to developing novel and appropriate applications for this new technology.

Intellectual Merit

In this project we examined responses of brain cells to AgNPs both in the dish and in the brains of rats who were fed AgNPs for two weeks. We found that exposure to AgNPs changes how cells control several internal mechanisms that alter their skeletons, resulting in loss of cell shapes that are critical to function. New brain cells were made differently in the brains of rats exposed to AgNPs compared to control. Importantly, the brains of rats collected immediately after AgNP treatment contained the same amount of Ag as the brains that were collected a month after treatment. This indicates that once AgNPs get into the brain, they are not excreted. Thus, even low levels of environmental exposure may result in significant amounts of Ag in the brain over time. Therefore, further investigation of how low levels of AgNPs interact with brain cells is warranted.

Broader Impacts

This work was carried out by a primarily undergraduate workforce at Marshall University which serves a predominantly rural population in West Virginia, including a high proportion of students who are the first in their family to attend college. Over the course of the project, 26 undergraduate students, many of whom performed research over multiple semesters or years, and four master's students were trained in the PI's lab. A significant number of students who worked on this project went on to competitive postgraduate programs or science careers.

This project supported Brain Expo at Marshall University. This event was attended by about 800 elementary school children annually and involved over 20 stations with hands-on activities teaching about the nervous system, how it works, what it does for you, and how to take care of it. Stations were presented primarily by undergraduate students who served as accessible role models for the children, shared their enthusiasm for science, and learned how to communicate science to the public. The Herd Science program took select Brain Expo stations on school visits throughout the academic years. We also hosted annual visits to campus where 5th grade students performed dissections with undergraduates to learn about how animals work. Finally, the PI developed a 'Science Communication' course with writing intensive certification that is open to all science majors. This course was offered three times over the course of the project and is now a part of the PI's regular teaching rotation.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/07/2022
Modified by: Nadja Spitzer
